awd_titl_txt: Manipulating Ligand Fields: Can 1st Row Transition Elements Behave as Their 2nd Row Congeners?
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry supports Prof. Peter T. Wolczanski, Chemistry Department, Cornell University, for research into imparting properties associated 2nd transition elements to 1st transition series elements. Many important commercial applications of transition metals use expensive, heavier elements that often pose significant health risks. This proposal seeks replacement compounds that contain earth abundant, less toxic, base- metals, hence first row transition metal complexes are the general focus. A significant product of this research is the human element; the generation of independent, versatile PhDs capable of adapting to a challenging market, which encompasses academic, industrial, government, and entrepreneurial occupations. The work will be disseminated through the scientific literature, in professional meetings, in the patent literature should the situation arise, and via other appropriate public forums. 

	Iron is targeted specifically for utilization in olefin metathesis, and "redox non-innocent" (RNI) organic ligands are also featured, due to their ability to enhance chemical reactivity by giving or taking electrons from the metal. Special emphasis is given to compounds and transformations that pertain to future catalytic and environmentally friendly applications. A fundamental understanding of ionic vs. covalent character is naturally addressed via the studies of RNI, and comparisons of transition metal reactivity. The scientific product of the research is the expansion of general knowledge regarding first row transition metal electronic structure, and concomitant reactivity. A desktop methodology for determining chemical stability, which provides insight into differences between first row transition metals and their heavier congeners, is under development, thus providing an additional pedagogical product.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A. Broader Impacts. 1.  Research Impact. The major theme of investigating 1st row TMs as potential replacements of catalytically or stoichiometrically important 2nd and 3rd row TM compounds has been advanced. Studies of diamide-diimine ligand, (dadi)n, reveal ligand reactivity as a direct consequence of the chelate redox non-innocence (RNI): 1) (dadi)2- behaves as an imine; 2) (dadi)4- as an eneamide; and 3) radical reactivity derives from (dadi)3-. The reactions show how RNI can expand the reactivity of TMs, in a sense substituting for covalency, and that electronic structure is crucial to understanding their nature. Further elaboration, where reversible reactivity of the chelate can expand its RNI capability is anticipated. A formally Fe(IV) imido complex was shown to be highly covalent, but a corresponding alkylidene eluded preparation, suggesting that complexes capable of conventional olefin metathesis may not be feasible. Dispersion forces, and increasing s-character of Fe-R linkages are both critical elements to Fe(IV)-alkyl stability, and may be design elements in synthesis.

            2.  Pedagogical Impact. a.  Outreach at Ithaca High School.  Outreach was conducted with 6 (3 women) Ithaca High School students (36 contact-h with PTW group; ~20 preparation-h), after vetting by a summer student from IHS. b. Charge Distribution Via Reporters. Further development of Charge Distribution Via Reporters (CDVR), a benchtop means of partitioning charge in a molecule without the aid of a computer, is ongoing, and scrutiny of metric data is being assessed to develop charges for ligands that lack spectroscopic handles. This concept provides a reality check to those who overinterpret the oxidation state formalism.

     3.  Human Resources. Jjudicious planning enabled 7 grad students (GS), one staff scientist, and 3 UG to receive partial NSF support over the ~36 mos. of the grant.  Two PhD's were granted, and students presented their research at the Western New York Inorganic Symposium. The research was also presented at the 2017 (lecture), 2018, and 2019 (posters) Organometallics Gordon Conferences, and ACS Meetings in Washington DC (2017) and Orlando, FL (2019).

B.  Intellectual Merit. Research and Publications. 1. Previous NSF Research. A tutorial featuring 12+ years of NSF sponsored work in addressing the activation of carbon-hydrogen bonds via the 1,2-RH-addition to high oxidation state, early metal YnM=NR complexes was published in Organometallics. A final publication on tungsten imido chemistry featured anionic derivatives prepared via the reaction of alkyllithiums and (tBu3SiN=)2(tBu3SiNH)WH.

     2. Fe(IV) Imide Dialkyl Insertion. A number of Fe(II) dialkyls LnFeR2 (Ln = tmeda, R = neoPe, 1; Ln = Me2IPr, R =  neoPe, 2a, 1-nor, 2b) were prepared for attempts to generate Fe(IV)=Y, with the rationale that three coordination was favorable for conversion to a pseudo-Td species. Exposure of Fe(II) dialkyls 2a,b to adamantyl azide (AdN3) afforded a transiently stable imidos, (Me2IPr)Fe=NAd(R)2 (R = 3a, b). In rare examples of insertion involving formal oxidation state changes, both imides converted to Fe(II) amide-alkyls 4a (3a->4a); ∆H‡ = 22.3(8) kcal/mol, ∆S‡ = 6.5(1) eu) and 4b (∆H‡ = 24.4(6) kcal/mol, ∆S‡ = 1.3(1) eu).The faster rate of the 3a vs. 3b was a consequence of a linear free energy change in the insertions to 4a,b, and small, but critical dispersion factors.

     3. Masked Fe Alkylidenes. The concept of masking an iron alkylidenewas tested via the synthesis of several (PNP)FeXY species, where the N of the PNP ligand can be used to "trap" a CR2 fragment as a zwitterion. Attempts to install the CR2 functionality failed, and comments regarding difficulties in preparing an Fe(IV) alkylidene were expressed.

     4. Metrics of dadi2- and dadi4-, and Cyclopropanation. Dadi, a diamide/diimine ligand capable of at least five redox states, was evaluated via titanium chemistry. Adducts [(dadi)TiX/L]n (n = -1 (6-XM), X = Me, neoPe, Vy, C2Ph, H/D, N3, OiPr, Cl; n = 0 (6-L), L = THF, N2CPh2) were prepared and  metric data were consistent with a tetraamide, whereas data  obtained from (dadi)Ti=NAd (7=NAd), and (dadi)Ti=O (7=O) defined the chelate dianionic form (dadi2-). A low lying NCCN pi*-orbital is occupied by 2e- in the former and empty in the latter. When THF adduct (dadi)Ti(THF) (6-THF) was treated with PhHCN2, cyclopropanation of the dadi backbone occurred, and calculations suggest that many "carbene transfers" are likely to be Lewis acid activations of diazoalkanes.

     5. Oxidative Addition at (dadi)4-. Depending on its redox state, (dadi)n can function as an ene-amide (n = 4-), a radical (n =3-) or a diimine (n = 2-). Treatment of 6-THF with RX (R = Me, Bn; X = Cl, Br) afforded alkylations at dadi akin to SN2 processes, like textbook RX additions to d8 Ir(I). Radical processes were eliminated when radical clocks, such as cPrCH2Br, failed to rearrange.Oxidations at the metal incurred rearranged products as the (dadi)2- was subject to internal Nu: attack. When imido (dadi)Ti=NAd (7=NAd) was treated with PhMe2PO, it rearranged to benzdiamide (bida)Ti=NAd-(OPMe2Ph) (14=NAd(OP)).


Last Modified: 08/04/2020
Modified by: Peter T Wolczanski
